member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon
member.summary: Entry point for a UI add-on.
member.remarks: Add-ons are a plugin-like system that allow mods to extend the UI capabilities through new views, tags, converters, and other features. All add-ons must be registered via .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon.Id
member.summary: Unique ID for this addon.
member.remarks: Prevents two copies of the same addon from trying to run at the same time, and allows other addons to depend on the features of this one by adding it to their .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon.Dependencies
member.summary: List of dependencies, each corresponding to another , required by this addon.
member.remarks: Dependencies will always be loaded first. If any dependencies are missing, or if a cycle is detected (e.g. addon A depends on B which depends on A again) then the addon will be prevented from loading.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon.BehaviorFactory
member.summary: Provides user-defined behavior extensions that run on existing view types.
member.remarks: All user-defined behaviors have lower priority than the built-in behaviors; a UI add-on is not allowed to remap an existing behavior name to its own implementation. Within the set of user-defined behaviors, the priority is based on inverted load order; the last add-on to associate a particular name with some behavior type will be the one to always handle that name, as long as it is not a standard behavior name.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon.ValueConverterFactory
member.summary: Provides user-defined type conversions in addition to the standard conversions.
member.remarks: All user-defined converters have lower priority than the built-in converters, except for the duck-type converters and which are always considered last. Within the set of user-defined converters, the priority is based on inverted load order; the last add-on that registered a converter able to handle a particular type conversion will be the one chosen, as long as none of the standard conversions can apply.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon.ViewFactory
member.summary: Provides user-defined view types and enables them to be used with custom markup tags.
member.remarks: All user-defined views have lower priority than the built-in views; a UI add-on is not allowed to replace the behavior of a standard tag such as <label> or <lane>. Within the set of user-defined views, the priority is based on inverted load order; the last add-on to associate a particular tag with some view type will be the one to always handle that tag, as long as it is not a standard tag.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.IPropertyStates`1
member.summary: Provides methods for tracking and modifying state-based overrides for a view's property.

remarks.para: State overrides provide a clean priority scheme and reversion path for semantic states such as "hover" or "pressed". Instead of behaviors modifying an directly, they can instead push their override to the view's propert states, and as long as that override remains the topmost state, it is authoritative for that specific view and property. If it is later removed, then whichever other state is subsequently on top takes precedence.

Using this abstraction avoids the need for individual behaviors to save the previous value, and more importantly, prevents unintended conflicts between multiple behaviors each trying to act on the same property of the same view.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.IPropertyStates`1.Push(System.String,`0)
member.summary: Pushes a new state to the top of the stack, making it the active override.
member.remarks: If a state with the specified already exists on the stack, then this will remove the previous instance and add the new instance on top.
member.param: The name of the new state.
The property value to use when while the state is active.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.IPropertyStates`1.Replace(System.String,`0)
member.summary: Replaces the value associated with a specified state.
member.remarks: If no state with the specified is on the stack, then this does nothing. It will not push a new state.
member.param: The name of the state on the stack.
The new value to associate with the specified .

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.IPropertyStates`1.ReplaceOrPush(System.String,`0)
member.summary: Replaces any existing value associated with a specified state, or pushes a new state to the top of the stack if a previous state does not already exist.
member.param: The name of the new state.
The property value to associate with the specified .

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.PropertyStateList`1
member.summary: Simple list-based implementation of optimized for low override counts, typically fewer than 5 and never more than 10-20.
member.remarks: Internally uses a , which is memory-efficient and has fast appends, but requires shifting items when a state is removed from the middle of the list. This is suitable for small stacks (e.g. a pressed state on top of a hover state, where the latter might be removed before the former), but if the stacks become very large, i.e. having hundreds of items, then a different implementation such as linked list or linked hash set might be required. Pushing a new state also requires checking for the existing state first, which is faster than hashing for very small lists but, similar to removals, may be inefficient for very large ones.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.ViewBehavior`2.OnAttached
member.summary: Runs after the behavior is attached to a target.
member.remarks: Setup code should go in this method to ensure that the values of and are actually assigned. If code runs in the behavior's constructor, these are not guaranteed to be populated.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.ViewBehavior`2.OnDetached(StardewUI.IView)
member.summary: Runs when the behavior is detached from a target.

remarks.para: Behaviors may receive new views as part of a "rebind", if the old view is destroyed and recreated, for example as the result of a conditional binding changing states.

OnDetached is always immediately followed by . A behavior cannot remain in a detached state; however, overriding this method gives behaviors the opportunity to clean up state from the old view (e.g. remove event handlers) before the new one is attached.
Also runs when the behavior is disposed, so detach logic does not need to be duplicated in .

member.param: The view that was previously attached.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.ViewBehavior`2.OnDispose
member.summary: Runs when the behavior is being disposed.
member.remarks: The default implementation does nothing. Overriding this allows subclasses to perform their own cleanup, if required by the specific feature.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.ViewBehavior`2.OnNewData(`1)
member.summary: Runs when the of this behavior is changed.
member.remarks: At the time this method runs, has already been assigned to the new value. After the method completes, the will no longer be accessible to this behavior.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Behaviors.VisibilityStateBehavior`1
member.summary: Behavior that applies a property override when a view enters or leaves the visible state.
member.remarks: The override is added when the view's becomes and removed when it becomes . In addition, the state corresponding to the view's initial visibility is applied as soon as the behavior as initialized, allowing for transitions to occur when the view is first created even if the visibility never explicitly changes.

member.param: Name of the overridden property.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Binding.BinaryCondition
member.summary: A condition based on the comparison of two values.

remarks.para: Passes whenever both values are equal. Used for *switch and *case attributes.

Any type may be used for either operand, but a conversion must be available from one of the types to the other type in order for the condition to ever pass. If the two types are different, and conversion both ways is possible, then priority will be given to the type implementing on itself; if the best type is still ambiguous, then left->right conversion will be chosen over right->left.

member.param: The factory responsible for creating instances from attribute data.
The factory responsible for creating instances, used to convert bound values to the types required by the target view.
Scope for resolving any externalized values, such as translation keys.
The attribute containing the expression for the LHS operand.
Scope for resolving any externalized values, such as translation keys.
The attribute containing the expression for the RHS operand.

member.summary: Binding instance for a single attribute on a single view.

member.summary: The name of the bound property on the destination view.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Binding.IAttributeBinding.GetBoundValue
member.summary: Gets the current value bound for this attribute, regardless of the view's actual value.

remarks.para: This method performs conversion (if necessary) from the source type to the destination type, but does not look at the destination view itself. It can be used to determine what the view's value "should be", which is part of the behavior system.
Alternatively, this can be thought of as the value that the view would have after calling with the force argument set to true.

member.returns: The currently bound value, or null if the value does not exist or cannot be determined, for example in the case of an .

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Content.IResolutionScope
member.summary: Defines a scope in which certain types of external and potentially ambiguous binding attributes may be resolved.
member.remarks: In general, resolution scopes are used where a document may include an unqualified or short-form reference, for which such a reference means to look in the same mod that originally provided that document.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Content.IResolutionScope.GetTranslation(System.String)
member.summary: Attempts to obtain a translation value with the given key.
member.param: The qualified or unqualified translation key. Unqualified keys are identical to their name in the translation file (i.e. in i18n/default.json), while qualified keys include a prefix with the specific mod, e.g. authorname.ModName:TranslationKey.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Content.IResolutionScope.GetTranslationValue(System.String)
member.summary: Attempts to obtain the string value of a translation with the given key.
member.remarks: Unless specifically overridden, calling this is normally the same as , except that it returns instead of , of which the latter is not instantiable outside of SMAPI's internals. To maintain consistency, code that reads translations should always use GetTranslationValue, while code that provides translations (i.e. implementations of ) should only implement GetTranslation, and leave this method alone.
member.param: The qualified or unqualified translation key. Unqualified keys are identical to their name in the translation file (i.e. in i18n/default.json), while qualified keys include a prefix with the specific mod, e.g. authorname.ModName:TranslationKey.
member.returns:
One of:
The translation, if available in the current language
The default-language (usually English) string, if the exists but no translation is available;
A translation with placeholder text, if the cannot be resolved to a known translation in a known mod.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Converters.DuckTypeClassConverterFactory
member.summary: Factory that creates duck-typing converters for class and struct types.
member.remarks:
For the conversion to be allowed:
The TDestination type must be annotated with .
The destination type must have either a default constructor, or a constructor that can be completely satisfied by properties/fields of the TSource type.
If the best or only constructor match is the default/parameterless constructor, at least one writable property on the target type must be satisfied by a property/field on the source type.
Additionally, source types may use fields or properties, but only constructor arguments and properties will be considered on the destination type.
member.param: The converter factory to handle conversion of individual properties/arguments.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Converters.DuckTypeClassConverterFactory.#ctor(StardewUI.Framework.Converters.IValueConverterFactory)
member.summary: Factory that creates duck-typing converters for class and struct types.
member.remarks:
For the conversion to be allowed:
The TDestination type must be annotated with .
The destination type must have either a default constructor, or a constructor that can be completely satisfied by properties/fields of the TSource type.
If the best or only constructor match is the default/parameterless constructor, at least one writable property on the target type must be satisfied by a property/field on the source type.
Additionally, source types may use fields or properties, but only constructor arguments and properties will be considered on the destination type.
member.param: The converter factory to handle conversion of individual properties/arguments.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Converters.TransformConverter
member.summary: String converter for the type.

remarks.para: Valid strings must be a semicolon-separated list of one of the valid transform properties, followed by a colon, followed by the property value.
Valid property names include: translate, translateX, translateY, rotate, scale, scaleX and scaleY.

The value following each property should be a number, except for translate and scale which should be a compatible string such as 2, -4 instead. Rotation values are interpreted as instead of radians for improved readability.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Descriptors.IPropertyDescriptor.IsAutoProperty
member.summary: Whether or not the property is likely auto-implemented.

remarks.para: Auto-property detection is heuristic, relying on the method's IL instructions and the name of its backing field. This can often be interpreted as a signal that the property won't receive property-change notifications, since to do so (whether explicitly or via some weaver/source generator) requires an implementation that is different from the auto-generated getter and setter.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.Descriptors.IPropertyDescriptor.IsField
member.summary: Whether or not the underlying member is a field, rather than a real property.
member.remarks: For binding convenience, fields and properties are both called "properties" for descriptors, as the external access pattern is the same; however, mutable fields can never reliably emit property-change notifications regardless of whether the declaring type implements , so this is usually used to emit some warning.

member.summary: A read-only binding which obtains the value from a translation key registered with SMAPI.

member.summary: A one-way data binding which obtains the value from the context data and assigns it to the view.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.AttributeValueType.OneTimeBinding
member.summary: A special type of that only reads the value a single time, and does not update subsequently afterward.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.AttributeValueType.TwoWayBinding
member.summary: A two-way data binding which both assigns the context data's value to the view, and the view's value to the context data, depending on which one was most recently changed.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType
member.summary: Types of tokens allowed in StarML.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown token; used when a lexer has not been initialized, or has reached the end of its content.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.OpeningTagStart
member.summary: Start of an opening tag, i.e. the < character without a subsequent /.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ClosingTagStart
member.summary: Start of a closing tag, i.e. the </ character sequence.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.TagEnd
member.summary: End of a regular opening or closing tag, i.e. the > character.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.SelfClosingTagEnd
member.summary: End of a self-closing tag, i.e. the /> character sequence.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Name
member.summary: A valid name, i.e. of an element (tag) or attribute.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.NameSeparator
member.summary: The dot (.) character used to separate components of a name.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.AttributeModifier
member.summary: Modifier token designating the type of an attribute; the * character (structural) or + (behavior).

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Literal
member.summary: A string of literal text, as found within a quoted or bound attribute.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Assignment
member.summary: The = character, as used in an attribute syntax such as attr="value".

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Negation
member.summary: The ! character, sometimes used to negate the value of an attribute, e.g. for conditional attributes.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Quote
member.summary: Double quote character (") used to start or terminate a string.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.BindingStart
member.summary: A pair of opening braces ({{), used to start a binding expression for an attribute value.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.BindingEnd
member.summary: A pair of closing braces (}}), used to end a binding expression for an attribute value.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.BindingModifier
member.summary: An explicit binding modifier; one of @ (asset), # (translation), & (template), < (input only), > (output only) or <> (two-way).

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ContextParent
member.summary: A caret (^) used in a binding expression, indicating a walk up to the parent context.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ContextAncestor
member.summary: A tilde (~) used in a binding expression, indicating traversal up to a parent with a named type.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.Pipe
member.summary: The pipe (|) character, which is used to start and end event bindings.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ArgumentListStart
member.summary: The left parenthesis (() character, used to start an argument list.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ArgumentListEnd
member.summary: The right parenthesis (() character, used to end an argument list.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ArgumentPrefix
member.summary: Prefix character for an argument, e.g. $ to refer to an event property.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Framework.Grammar.TokenType.ArgumentSeparator
member.summary: The comma (,) character, used to separator arguments in an argument list.

member.summary: Beginning of a comment block (<!--).

member.summary: A marker interface that, when used in place of , forces the framework to attempt an explicit conversion/cast to the expected destination type.
member.remarks: Casts are normally only permitted when the source type is actually assignable to the destination type. IAnyCast is used to indicate that the source is intentionally ambiguous or boxed, and the real type cannot be known until the conversion is attempted, at which point it is assumed to be assignment-compatible or have an explicit conversion operator.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.CreateMenuControllerFromAsset(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a menu from the StarML stored in a game asset, as provided by a mod via SMAPI or Content Patcher, and returns a controller for customizing the menu's behavior.
member.remarks: The menu that is created is the same as the result of . The menu is not automatically shown; to show it, use or equivalent.
member.param: The name of the StarML view asset in the content pipeline, e.g. Mods/MyMod/Views/MyView.
The context, or "model", for the menu's view, which holds any data-dependent values. Note: The type must implement in order for any changes to this data to be automatically reflected in the UI.
member.returns: A controller object whose is the created menu and whose other properties can be used to change menu-level behavior.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.EnableHotReloading(System.String)
member.summary: Starts monitoring this mod's directory for changes to assets managed by any of the Register methods, e.g. views and sprites.

remarks.para: If the argument is specified, and points to a directory with the same asset structure as the mod, then an additional sync will be set up such that files modified in the sourceDirectory while the game is running will be copied to the active mod directory and subsequently reloaded. In other words, pointing this at the mod's .csproj directory allows hot reloading from the source files instead of the deployed mod's files.
Hot reload may impact game performance and should normally only be used during development and/or in debug mode.

member.param: Optional source directory to watch and sync changes from. If not specified, or not a valid source directory, then hot reload will only pick up changes from within the live mod directory.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.PreloadAssets
member.summary: Begins preloading assets found in this mod's registered asset directories.

remarks.para: Preloading is performed in the background, and can typically help reduce first-time latency for showing menus or drawables, without any noticeable lag in game startup.
Must be called after asset registration (, and so on) in order to be effective, and must not be called more than once per mod otherwise errors or crashes may occur.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.PreloadModels(System.Type[])
member.summary: Declares that the specified context types will be used as either direct arguments or subproperties in one or more subsequent CreateMenu or CreateDrawable APIs, and instructs the framework to begin inspecting those types and optimizing for later use.
member.remarks: Data binding to mod-defined types uses reflection, which can become expensive when loading a very complex menu and/or binding to a very complex model for the first time. Preloading can perform this work in the background instead of causing latency when opening the menu.
member.param: The types that the mod expects to use as context.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.RegisterCustomData(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Registers a mod directory to be searched for special-purpose mod data, i.e. that is not either views or sprites.
member.remarks:
Allowed extensions for files in this folder and their corresponding data types are:
.buttonspritemap.json - ButtonSpriteMapData
member.param: The prefix for all asset names, excluding the category which is deduced from the file extension as described in the remarks. For example, given a value of Mods/MyMod, a file named foo.buttonspritemap.json would be referenced in views as @Mods/MyMod/ButtonSpriteMaps/Foo.
The physical directory where the asset files are located, relative to the mod directory. Typically a path such as assets/ui or assets/ui/data.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.RegisterSprites(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Registers a mod directory to be searched for sprite (and corresponding texture/sprite sheet data) assets.
member.param: The prefix for all asset names, e.g. Mods/MyMod/Sprites. This can be any value but the same prefix must be used in @AssetName view bindings.
The physical directory where the asset files are located, relative to the mod directory. Typically a path such as assets/sprites or assets/ui/sprites.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine.RegisterViews(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Registers a mod directory to be searched for view (StarML) assets. Uses the .sml extension.
member.param: The prefix for all asset names, e.g. Mods/MyMod/Views. This can be any value but the same prefix must be used in include elements and in API calls to create views.
The physical directory where the asset files are located, relative to the mod directory. Typically a path such as assets/views or assets/ui/views.

member.summary: Gets or sets a function that returns whether or not the menu can be closed.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to implementing .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.IMenuController.CloseAction
member.summary: Gets or sets an action that replaces the default menu-close behavior.
member.remarks: Most users should leave this property unset. It is intended for use in unusual contexts, such as replacing the mod settings in a Generic Mod Config Menu integration. Setting any non-null value to this property will suppress the default behavior of entirely, so the caller is responsible for handling all possible scenarios (e.g. child of another menu, or sub-menu of the title menu).

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.IMenuController.CloseButtonOffset
member.summary: Offset from the menu view's top-right edge to draw the close button.
member.remarks: Only applies when has been called at least once.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.IMenuController.CloseOnOutsideClick
member.summary: Whether to automatically close the menu when a mouse click is detected outside the bounds of the menu and any floating elements.
member.remarks: This setting is primarily intended for submenus and makes them behave more like overlays.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.IMenuController.DimmingAmount
member.summary: How much the menu should dim the entire screen underneath.
member.remarks: The default dimming is appropriate for most menus, but if the menu is being drawn as a delegate of some other macro-menu, then it can be lowered or removed (set to 0) entirely.

member.summary: Closes the menu.
member.remarks: This method allows programmatic closing of the menu. It performs the same action that would be performed by pressing one of the configured menu keys (e.g. ESC), clicking the close button, etc., and follows the same rules, i.e. will not allow closing if is false.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.IMenuController.SetGutters(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Configures the menu's gutter widths/heights.

remarks.para: Gutters are areas of the screen that the menu should not occupy. These are typically used with a menu whose root view uses for one of its dimensions, and allows limiting the max width/height relative to the viewport size.
The historical reason for gutters is overscan, however they are still commonly used for aesthetic reasons.

member.param: The gutter width on the left side of the viewport.
The gutter height at the top of the viewport.
The gutter width on the right side of the viewport. The default value of -1 specifies that the value should be mirrored on the right.
The gutter height at the bottom of the viewport. The default value of -1 specifies that the value should be mirrored on the bottom.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.ViewEngineExtensions.EnableHotReloadingWithSourceSync(StardewUI.Framework.IViewEngine,System.String)
member.summary: Starts monitoring this mod's directory for changes to assets managed by any of the 's Register methods, e.g. views and sprites, and attempts to set up an additional sync from the mod's project (source) directory to the deployed mod directory so that hot reloads can be initiated from the IDE.

remarks.para: Callers should normally omit the parameter in their call; this will cause it to be replaced at compile time with the actual file path of the caller, and used to automatically detect the project path.
If detection/sync fails due to an unusual project structure, consider providing an exact path directly to instead of using this extension.
Hot reload may impact game performance and should normally only be used during development and/or in debug mode.

member.param: The view engine API.
Do not pass in this argument, so that can provide the correct value on build.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.PerformanceConfig.EnableParallelDescriptors
member.summary: Whether to process member descriptors of a view or model in parallel.
member.remarks: Parallel processing will often make first-time loads slower rather than faster, due to scheduling overhead and some synchronization. This may be beneficial if types with hundreds of fields/properties are involved.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Framework.PerformanceConfig.EnableReflectionWarmup
member.summary: Whether to warm up StardewUI's reflection cache on a background thread during game start.
member.remarks: This will usually improve first-time loads of menus by 10-20%, and tends to have no cost/imperceptible cost on app startup, since it uses only one background thread (no parallelism) and other startup tasks tend to run on main thread only.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Framework.Sources.IValueSource.Update(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Checks if the value needs updating, and if so, updates to the latest.
member.remarks: This method is called every frame, for every binding, and providing a correct return value is essential in order to avoid slowdowns due to unnecessary rebinds.
member.param: If true, forces the source to update its value even if it isn't considered dirty. This should never be used in a regular binding, but can be useful in sources that are intended for occasional or one-shot use such as event handler arguments.
member.returns: true if the was updated; false if it already held the most recent value.

member.summary: Adapter for a drop-down list with a dynamic value type, i.e. that can change the type of its option list, formatter, etc. according to the current bindings.
member.remarks: This class is only intended for framework use. When creating drop-down lists in custom widgets or app views, callers should use the generic instead. member.summary: Entry point for Stardew UI. Must be called from .

member.summary: The add-ons registered so far.

member.name: M:StardewUI.UI.RegisterAddon(StardewUI.Framework.Addons.IAddon)
member.summary: Registers a UI add-on (mod extension).

remarks.para: Add-ons are resolved in the game's event. Therefore, mods providing add-ons must register them as early as possible, typically in their method, but if that is too early, then in a GameLaunched handler of their own with a high .

Types provided by add-ons (views, converters, etc.) will not actually be used until a UI is created, so add-ons may employ lazy/deferred loading if they need to postpone some critical operations until after the game is fully loaded, other APIs are initialized, etc.

member.param: The add-on definition.

member.name: M:StardewUI.UI.ResolveLoadOrder
member.summary: For all add-ons registered so far, determines a correct load order such that all dependencies are met.
member.remarks: Any add-ons whose dependencies cannot be satisfied will be excluded from the load order, and errors will be logged for any dependencies that failed to load.
member.returns: A safe load order for registered add-ons.

member.summary: The border sprite to draw for this frame.
member.remarks: Setting a border here does not affect layout, even if are set to non-zero values, since fixed edges only govern scaling and are not necessarily the same as the actual edge thicknesses. To ensure that inner content does not overlap with the border, should also be set when using a border.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Frame.BorderThickness
member.summary: The thickness of the border edges.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Frame.HorizontalContentAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how to align the horizontally within the frame's area. Only has an effect if the frame's content area is larger than the content size, i.e. when does not use .

member.summary: Alpha value for the shadow. If set to the default of zero, no shadow will be drawn.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Frame.ShadowCount
member.summary: Number of shadows to draw if is non-zero.
member.remarks: While rare, some game sprites are supposed to be drawn with multiple stacked shadows. If this number is higher than the default of 1, shadows will be drawn stacked with the offset repeatedly applied.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Frame.ShadowOffset
member.summary: Offset to draw the sprite shadow, which is a second copy of the drawn entirely black. Shadows will not be visible unless is non-zero.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Frame.VerticalContentAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how to align the vertically within the frame's area. Only has an effect if the frame's content area is larger than the content size, i.e. when does not use .

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.GhostView
member.summary: A view that draws an exact copy of another view, generally with a tint and transparency to indicate that it is not the original view. Can be used for dragging, indicating target snap positions, etc.
member.remarks: The must be part of a real layout in order for the ghosting to work correctly; does no layout or layout-forwarding of its own.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.GhostView.RealView
member.summary: The view for which a copy will be drawn.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.GhostView.TintColor
member.summary: Color of the ghost.
member.remarks: This tint is multiplied against the 's pixel values and acts as a recolor; for example, specifying here will result in the ghost being entirely red and black.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid
member.summary: A uniform grid containing other views.
member.remarks: Can be configured to use either a fixed cell size, and therefore a variable number of rows and columns depending on the grid size, or a fixed number of rows and columns, with a variable size per cell.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.Children
member.summary: Child views to display in this layout, arranged according to the .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.GridAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how to align the entire grid when the combined length of all columns is not exactly equal to the grid's layout length.
member.remarks: Applies only to the grid's axis, which is the axis affected by ; the secondary axis does not require or support grid-level alignment because it can already be made -sized.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.HorizontalItemAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how to align each child horizontally within its respective cell, i.e. if the view is narrower than the cell's width.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.ItemLayout
member.summary: The layout for items (cells) in this grid.

remarks.para: Layouts are relative to the . specifies the number of columns when , and number of rows when ; similarly, specifies the column width when horizontal and row height when vertical. The other dimension is determined by the individual item's own .
Note that this affects the limits for individual items, not necessarily their exact size. Children may be smaller than the cells that contain them, and if so are positioned according to the and .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.ItemSpacing
member.summary: Spacing between the edges of adjacent columns () and rows ().
member.remarks: Setting this is roughly equivalent to specifying the same on each child, except that it will not add extra space before the first item or after the last item.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.PrimaryOrientation
member.summary: Specifies the axis that items are added to before wrapping.

remarks.para: means children are added from left to right, and when reaching the edge or max column count, start over at the beginning of the next row. means children flow from top to bottom, and when reaching the bottom, wrap to the top of the next column.

Also affects which dimension is fixed and which is potentially unbounded. Horizontally-oriented grids have a fixed width and can grow to any height (if is set to ). Vertically-oriented grids are the opposite, having a fixed height and growing to an arbitrary width.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Grid.VerticalItemAlignment
member.summary: Specifies how to align each child vertically within its respective cell, i.e. if the view is shorter than the cell's height.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.Image
member.summary: A view that draws a sprite, scaled to the layout size.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.Fit
member.summary: How to fit the image in the content area, if sizes differ.
member.remarks: The fit setting is always ignored when both the and use , because that combination of settings will cause the exact (or texture bounds, if not specified) as the layout size. At least one dimension must be content-independent (fixed or container size) for this to have any effect.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: Specifies where to align the image horizontally if the image width is different from the final layout width.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.Rotation
member.summary: Rotation to apply to the image.
member.remarks: Unlike , rotation potentially does affect layout under specific conditions; specifically, if any dimensions are sized, and the rotation is 90 in either direction, it will take the opposite dimension for layout. However, images whose dimensions are entirely fixed or stretch-based will not have their layout affected.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.Scale
member.summary: Scale to apply to the image.
member.remarks: This scale acts only as a drawing transformation and does not affect layout; a scaled-up image can potentially draw (or clip) outside its container, and a scaled-down image will not shrink the size of an image that specifies for either or both dimensions.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.ShadowAlpha
member.summary: Alpha value for the shadow. If set to the default of zero, no shadow will be drawn.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.ShadowOffset
member.summary: Offset to draw the sprite shadow, which is a second copy of the drawn entirely black. Shadows will not be visible unless is non-zero.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.Sprite
member.summary: The sprite to draw.
member.remarks: If uses for either dimension, then changing the sprite can affect layout depending on .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.SpriteEffects
member.summary: Sprite effects to apply, such as horizontal or vertical flipping.
member.remarks: Effects are applied only during and do not affect layout.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.Tint
member.summary: Tint color (multiplier) to apply when drawing.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Image.VerticalAlignment
member.summary: Specifies where to align the image vertically if the image height is different from the final layout height.

member.summary: The text color.

member.summary: The font that will be used to render the text.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Label.HorizontalAlignment
member.summary: How to align the text horizontally.
member.remarks:
This acts differently from setting an on the container view as it applies to each individual line of text rather than the entire block of text.
For example, center-aligned text looks like:
+--------------------------------------------+ | The quick brown fox jumps | | over the lazy dog | +--------------------------------------------+
While left-aligned text that is centered in the container looks like:
+--------------------------------------------+ | The quick brown fox jumps | | over the lazy dog | +--------------------------------------------+
Alignment behavior is also sensitive to the width settings in . and may have no effect if the width type is set to ; for non-default alignments to work, one of the other length types is required.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Label.MaxLines
member.summary: Maximum number of lines of text to display when wrapping. Default is 0 which applies no limit.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Label.Scale
member.summary: Font scaling to apply. Default is 1.0 (normal size).
member.remarks: Applies only to the text itself and not layout properties such as .

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Label.ShadowAlpha
member.summary: Alpha value for the text shadow, per layer in .
member.remarks: If set to zero, no text shadow will be drawn.

member.summary: Base color for the text shadow, before applying .

member.remarks: Layers are additive, so the same will have a different visual intensity depending on which layers are allowed. If set to , then no shadow will be drawn.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.Marquee
member.summary: A scrolling marquee supporting any inner content.
member.remarks: Works by doubling and shifting the drawing the portion and applying a clipping rectangle, and therefore should be used only for non-interactive content; clicks and focus searches will not be correct inside the content area.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Marquee.Content

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Marquee.ExtraDistance
member.summary: Distance in pixels between the copy of the content being scrolled "out" of the marquee, and the second copy of the content being scrolled "in".
member.remarks:
For example, a marquee scrolling the text "Hello World" might at any given moment look like:
+----------------+ | ld Hello wor | +----------------+
and in the above scenario the value refers to the distance between the ending "d" and the starting "H".

member.summary: A layout view whose children all overlap the same boundaries.

remarks.para: A panel's content size (i.e. if any dimensions are ) is always equal to the largest child; alignment applies to each child individually, and children are drawn according to their first and then their order in .
Children can be positioned more precisely using their and for standard view types, or drawing at non-origin positions for custom implementations.
A common use of panels is to draw overlapping images, in cases where a doesn't really make sense, e.g. there is no explicit "background" or "border", or if there are more than 2 layers to draw.

member.remarks: The created panel will stretch to fill all available area, and align the view within itself according to the and alignments. Several helpers can be used to align different content/controls to different edges or corners of the same parent .

member.remarks: The primary content is always kept centered, with optional title, footer and sidebar (e.g. for navigation) available to decorate the view. Many if not most menus can be fully represented with this layout, as long as they do not have built-in subnavigation such as top-level tabs.

This acts as a maximum width; the actual sidebar does not have to fill this space (it will be right-aligned in that case), but larger views may clip or overflow.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.ScrollContainer
member.summary: Renders inner content clipped to a boundary and with a modifiable scroll offset.

remarks.para: Does not provide its own scroll bar; scrolling UI and behavior can be controlled via adding a to any other part of the UI.

While nothing prevents a from being set up with the dimension set to use , in general the container will only work correctly when the scrolled dimension is constrained ( or ). Scrolling behavior is enabled by providing an infinite available length to the view for layout, while constraining its own size.

Scrolling is not virtual. Regardless of the difference in size between scroll container and content, the full content will always be drawn on every frame, and simply clipped to the available area. This may therefore not be suitable for extremely long lists or other unbounded content.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Widgets.Keybinding.KeybindOverlay.KeybindType
member.summary: Specifies what kind of keybind is being edited.
member.remarks:
This determines the behavior of the capturing as well as what happens after capture:
displays the list of existing keybinds (if any), adds the captured keybind when all buttons/keys are released, and allows adding more;
does not display the list or separator, and when all buttons/keys are released, updates its to have that single keybind and closes the overlay.
is similar to but records the keybind and closes the overlay as soon as a single button is pressed.
Typically when using single-bind or single-button modes, the caller should upon creation of the overlay in order to minimize redundant clicks.

member.summary: Starts capturing a new keybind.
member.remarks: This makes the capture area start flashing and hides the "Add" button; any buttons pressed in the capturing state are recorded and combined into a single keybind after the capture ends, when all buttons are released.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.ComponentView`1
member.summary: Base class for custom widgets and "app views" with potentially complex hierarchy using a single root view.

remarks.para: This implements all the boilerplate of an without having to actually implement a totally custom ; instead, it delegates all functionality to the inner (root) .

The typical use case is for what is often called "Components", "Layouts", "User Controls", etc., in which a class defines both the view hierarchy and an API for interacting with the view and underlying data at the same time. The top-level layout is created in , and child views can be added on creation or at any later time. More importantly, since the subclass decides what children to create, it can also store references to those children for the purposes of updating the UI, responding to events, etc.
Component views can be composed like any other views, or used in a .

member.typeparam: Type of view used for the root.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Widgets.ComponentView`1.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of .

member.name: M:StardewUI.Widgets.ComponentView`1.CreateView
member.summary: Creates and returns the root view.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.DecoratorView`1
member.summary: A view that owns and delegates to an inner view.

remarks.para: Decorator views, while not abstract, are used as a base type for other composite views, and primarily intended for framework use. Custom widgets should normally use instead, which incorporates lazy loading and other conveniences for minimalistic implementations.

The inner view is considered to be owned by the decorator; it will be assigned any values that were assigned to the decorator itself, such as , and if it implements , then it will be disposed along with the decorator.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.ImageFit
member.summary: Specifies how an image should be scaled to fit the content area when the available size is different from the image size, and especially when it has a different aspect ratio.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Widgets.ImageFit.None
member.summary: Don't scale the image, i.e. draw it at its original size regardless of the eventual layout size.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Widgets.ImageFit.Contain
member.summary: Force uniform scaling, and make both dimensions small enough to fit in the content area.
member.remarks: If one dimension uses , then the other dimension will be scaled to fit, and the content-dependent dimension will be set according to the image's aspect ratio.

member.name: F:StardewUI.Widgets.ImageFit.Cover
member.summary: Force uniform scaling, and make both dimensions large enough to completely cover the content area (i.e. clip whatever parts are outside the bounds).

member.name: F:StardewUI.Widgets.ImageFit.Stretch
member.summary: Allow non-uniform scaling, and scale the image to exactly match the content area.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Widgets.OutletAttribute
member.summary: Marks a child/children property as a named outlet.

remarks.para: Outlets are used by the UI Framework, in StarML views, to differentiate between multiple child properties of the same layout view. For example, the defines both a view (the "main" view) and a separate view, but normally only one children/content property is allowed per layout view.

When a property is decorated with an OutletAttribute, it is ignored by the framework unless the markup element includes an *outlet attribute with a value equal to the outlet , in which case the element (or elements) will be added or assigned to that specific outlet.
The attribute should be omitted for whichever outlet is considered the default, i.e. to be targeted whenever the markup element does not include an *outlet attribute.
Has no effect when used outside a data binding context, or when applied to any property that does not have either or a collection of elements such as .

member.param: The outlet name, to be matched in an *outlet attribute.

When a property is decorated with an OutletAttribute, it is ignored by the framework unless the markup element includes an *outlet attribute with a value equal to the outlet , in which case the element (or elements) will be added or assigned to that specific outlet.
The attribute should be omitted for whichever outlet is considered the default, i.e. to be targeted whenever the markup element does not include an *outlet attribute.

Keyboard control schemes only specify the fine movements; alignments are always controlled using number/numpad keys for each of the 9 possibilities.

member.summary: The native scale at which to draw the sprite.

remarks.para: Sprites drawn as part of an are always scaled according to the layout dimensions and fit settings; specifying a non-unity scale here will also cause any to be scaled. This is meant for nine-slice sprites that need to scale borders up by a fixed amount (most often 4, sometimes 2) and the center slice by an arbitrary amount.
This setting is shorthand for since it is the most commonly used slice setting. Providing a non-default value will create the instance.

List of additional items required for crafting that are not included in the .

member.name: T:StardewUI.DuckPropertyAttribute
member.summary: Specifies a property name to use for duck-type conversions, if different from the member name.

remarks.para: This attribute is applied to the type being converted from, unlike which applies to the target type. It is used to match a target property with a different name, or to match multiple target properties with a single source field.

Multiple copies of the attribute can be used to match multiple target properties, with being used to optionally filter which type conversions it will apply to, if the data type might be used in more than one kind of conversion.

member.param: The name of the property to match on the target type.

Name of the conversion target type (i.e. type with ) to which this rename applies, not including the namespace or generic arguments. If not set, the property will be available under the specified for all conversions.

member.name: M:StardewUI.DuckPropertyAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies a property name to use for duck-type conversions, if different from the member name.

remarks.para: This attribute is applied to the type being converted from, unlike which applies to the target type. It is used to match a target property with a different name, or to match multiple target properties with a single source field.

Multiple copies of the attribute can be used to match multiple target properties, with being used to optionally filter which type conversions it will apply to, if the data type might be used in more than one kind of conversion.

member.param: The name of the property to match on the target type.

Name of the conversion target type (i.e. type with ) to which this rename applies, not including the namespace or generic arguments. If not set, the property will be available under the specified for all conversions.

member.name: P:StardewUI.DuckPropertyAttribute.TargetPropertyName
member.summary: The name of the property to match on the target type.

member.name: P:StardewUI.DuckPropertyAttribute.TargetTypeName
member.summary: Name of the conversion target type (i.e. type with ) to which this rename applies, not including the namespace or generic arguments. If not set, the property will be available under the specified for all conversions.

member.name: T:StardewUI.DuckTypeAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that a type is eligible for duck-type conversions in data bindings.

remarks.para: This attribute is not used by the core library, only the data binding framework. When a type is decorated with it, values of normally non-convertible types, such as user-defined types in a separate mod, can become eligible for conversion to the decorated type and have converters generated at runtime, as long as the external type's properties are sufficient to satisfy one of the decorated type's constructors; or, in the case of default constructors, when the external type can contribute at least one property value.

Duck type conversions always match using the combined property type and (case-insensitive) name. The name of the decorated type's property or constructor argument must match the name of the property on the source type, unless is specified, in which case it must match the specified name(s).

member.name: T:StardewUI.Graphics.GlobalTransform
member.summary: Global transform applied to an .

remarks.para: Because the in MonoGame/XNA has scale and rotation parameters for individual draw methods (whether texture or text), which are presumably more optimized than computing a new global transform matrix and restarting the sprite batch, the global transform maintains a current local transform and only "merges" it into the transform matrix once the accumulated local transform can no longer be represented in one .

These "local" transforms actually represent the model matrix, while the accumulated global transform is the view matrix, so the relationship between them is quirky; see for more details on the process.

Global transforms are always "around" the viewport origin (0, 0). To use a different origin relative to the current view, first translated by the negated origin position, then apply regular transforms, then translate by the (positive) origin position again.

member.param: The cumulative transformation matrix.
Local transform to apply after the takes effect.
Origin for the transform.

remarks.para: Because the in MonoGame/XNA has scale and rotation parameters for individual draw methods (whether texture or text), which are presumably more optimized than computing a new global transform matrix and restarting the sprite batch, the global transform maintains a current local transform and only "merges" it into the transform matrix once the accumulated local transform can no longer be represented in one .

These "local" transforms actually represent the model matrix, while the accumulated global transform is the view matrix, so the relationship between them is quirky; see for more details on the process.

Global transforms are always "around" the viewport origin (0, 0). To use a different origin relative to the current view, first translated by the negated origin position, then apply regular transforms, then translate by the (positive) origin position again.

member.param: The cumulative transformation matrix.
Local transform to apply after the takes effect.
Origin for the transform.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.ISpriteBatch.SaveTransform
member.summary: Saves the current transform, so that it can later be restored to its current state.
member.remarks: This is typically used in hierarchical layout; i.e. a view with children would apply a transform before handing the canvas or sprite batch down to any of those children, and then restore it after the child is done with it. This enables a single instance to be used for the entire layout rather than having to create a tree.
member.returns: A disposable instance which, when disposed, restores the transform of this to the same state it was in before SaveTransform was called.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Graphics.RenderTargetPool
member.summary: Pools instances so they can be reused across multiple frames.

remarks.para: Targets are pooled by their size, since render targets have a fixed size and changing the size requires recreating the target. The pooled targets are considered to be managed by the pool, and are disposed along with the pool itself; typically a pool is associated with some long-lived UI object such as a menu, and then assigned to a transient instance like .

Pools can be configured with a in order to increase long-term reuse at the expense of higher transient memory and/or VRAM usage due to the extra targets; these may be several megabytes if the areas to be captured are large. Slack can help accommodate dynamic views, e.g. different tabs with different scroll sizes, but should be used conservatively to avoid keeping long-dead targets.

The pool is effectively unbounded in the number of instances it can create, but once slack is exceeded, it will dispose an old instance before creating a new one, starting with the instance having the largest pixel size (i.e. taking up the most memory).

member.param: The graphics device used for rendering.
Specifies the maximum number of unused pooled render targets to keep, when requesting a new target whose size is not in the pool, before disposing an older target.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.RenderTargetPool.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32)

Pools can be configured with a in order to increase long-term reuse at the expense of higher transient memory and/or VRAM usage due to the extra targets; these may be several megabytes if the areas to be captured are large. Slack can help accommodate dynamic views, e.g. different tabs with different scroll sizes, but should be used conservatively to avoid keeping long-dead targets.

The pool is effectively unbounded in the number of instances it can create, but once slack is exceeded, it will dispose an old instance before creating a new one, starting with the instance having the largest pixel size (i.e. taking up the most memory).

member.param: The graphics device used for rendering.
Specifies the maximum number of unused pooled render targets to keep, when requesting a new target whose size is not in the pool, before disposing an older target.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Graphics.SliceSettings
member.summary: Additional nine-slice settings for dealing with certain "unique" structures.
member.param: The X position to use for the horizontal center slices, or null to start where the left fixed edge ends.
Specifies whether the should be understood as the start position or the end position of the horizontal center slice.
The Y position to use for the vertical center slices, or null to start where the top fixed edge ends.
Specifies whether the should be understood as the start position or the end position of the vertical center slice.
Scale to apply to the slices themselves; for example, if a 16x16 source draws to a 64x64 target, and a scale of 2 is used, then a 2x3 border slice would draw as 16x24 (normal 8x16, multiplied by 2).
If true, then only the outer 8 edge segments should be drawn, and the 9th (horizontal and vertical middle, i.e. "background") segment will be ignored.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Graphics.Transform
member.summary: Global transform applied to an .

remarks.para: The order of the different translation parameters reflects the actual order in which the transformations will be applied in a . Scaling before rotation prevents unexpected skewing, and rotating before translation keeps the coordinate system intact.
To deliberately apply the individual operations in a different order, use separate instances applied in sequence, or simply compute the directly.

member.param: The scale at which to draw. is unity scale (i.e. no scaling).
2D rotation (always along Z axis) to apply, in radians.
Translation offset for drawn content.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.Transform.CanMergeLocally(StardewUI.Graphics.Transform)
member.summary: Checks if a subsequent transform can be merged into this one while preserving the result as a simple local transform, i.e. not requiring the use of a transformation matrix.
member.remarks:
Local transforms can be merged if they are either:
Mathematically commutative with the existing properties, such as uniform scaling, or additional translation on a local transform that is only translation; or
Following the same transformation order that applies during the various and methods, i.e. followed by followed by . For example, if the current instance has and , and the transform has Rotation only, then the rotations can be trivially summed.
member.param: The local transformation to apply after the current instance.
member.returns: true if the cumulative sequence of transformations can continue to be represented as a simple local ; false if the combination requires converting and subsequent inclusion into a new .

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.Transform.CanMergeLocally(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,System.Single,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2)
member.summary: Checks if a subsequent transform, represented by its individual components, can be merged into this one while preserving the result as a simple local transform, i.e. not requiring the use of a transformation matrix.
member.param: The component of the next transform.
The component of the next transform.
The component of the next transform.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.Transform.IsRectangular
member.summary: Checks if this transform represents a single rectangular area of the parent, i.e. not rotated or skewed.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.Transform.ToMatrix
member.summary: Creates a transformation matrix from the properties of this transform.
member.remarks: The created matrix, when used with , will have the same effect as if the current , and were to be provided directly as arguments to the sprite or text drawing method(s).
member.returns: A transformation matrix equivalent to this transform.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Graphics.TransformOrigin
member.summary: Describes the origin point to use for a local .

remarks.para: Origin data needs to track two vectors; the relative or percentage position with and between 0 and 1 (e.g. the center of the layout would be (0.5, 0.5)) as well as the absolute or pixel position.

The relative position is used for individual drawing operations; when drawing a single sprite or text string, the XNA drawing APIs use this exact origin vector. The absolute position, on the other hand, is required for transform propagation in the , i.e. if the custom-origin transform is applied to a layout view, because it must be converted into a translation matrix.

member.param: The relative position with and values between 0 and 1, where (0, 0) is the top-left, (0.5, 0.5) is the middle, and (1, 1) is the bottom right.
The pixel position of the exact origin point, relative to the transformed view's top-left corner.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Graphics.TransformOrigin.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2)
member.summary: Describes the origin point to use for a local .

remarks.para: Origin data needs to track two vectors; the relative or percentage position with and between 0 and 1 (e.g. the center of the layout would be (0.5, 0.5)) as well as the absolute or pixel position.

The relative position is used for individual drawing operations; when drawing a single sprite or text string, the XNA drawing APIs use this exact origin vector. The absolute position, on the other hand, is required for transform propagation in the , i.e. if the custom-origin transform is applied to a layout view, because it must be converted into a translation matrix.

member.param: The relative position with and values between 0 and 1, where (0, 0) is the top-left, (0.5, 0.5) is the middle, and (1, 1) is the bottom right.
The pixel position of the exact origin point, relative to the transformed view's top-left corner.

member.name: P:StardewUI.Graphics.XeluButtonSpriteMap.SliceScale
member.summary: Scale to apply to nine-slice sprites, specifically keyboard blanks.

remarks.para: This setting exists because the sprite assets are much larger than the space available for a typical keybind image in a menu, which - very unusually for Stardew - means they need to be scaled down, not up. However, some UIs (e.g. some overlays) may want to display these sprites at their normal size or larger, and in these cases, should not scale the slices because the borders would look strange or hard to see.

In general, considering the base dimensions of 100x100, a comfortable size for menus targeting roughly 48px button height should use roughly 1/3 scale (0.3). Overlays and other UIs intending to render the sprite at full size (or larger) can leave the default of 1.

member.name: T:StardewUI.Input.ButtonResolver
member.summary: Helper for resolving button state reported by vanilla menu code.

remarks.para: Stardew's menu system is quite obnoxious about trying to "simplify" button handling and doesn't provide a lot of escape hatches. In addition, the buttons it considers to be the same are not equivalent to the way normal gameplay operates; for example, gamepad controls use A as the action button which is the same as a right-click when interacting with the game world; however, in menus A is the same as a left-click while X is right click.

Going through this class can help identify the correct "function" of a button in a UI context as well as identify which real button was actually pressed, the better to work with input suppressions and similar concerns.

member.returns: A button that performs the same action as and is currently pressed; or the original if no match can be found.

For example, view A is a layout with positioned child view C, which yields a search result targeting view Z in terms of its (C's) local coordinates. member.name: E:StardewUI.IView.ButtonPress

member.name: E:StardewUI.IView.ButtonRepeat
member.summary: Event raised when a button is being held while the view is in focus, and has been held long enough since the initial or the previous ButtonRepeat to trigger a repeated press.

remarks.para: Because the game has its own logic to repeat key presses, which would cause to fire repeatedly, this event generally applies only to the controller; that is, it exists to allow callers to decide whether they want the handler to repeat while the button is held or to only fire when first pressed, providing slightly more control than keyboard events whose repetition is up to the whims of the vanilla game.
Only the views in the current focus path should receive these events.

member.name: E:StardewUI.IView.DragStart

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.ActualBounds
member.summary: The bounds of this view relative to the origin (0, 0).

remarks.para: Typically, a view's bounds is the rectangle from (0, 0) having size of , but there may be a difference especially in the case of negative margins. The various sizes affect layout flow and can even be negative - for example, in a left-to-right layout, a view with left margin -100, right margin 20 and inner width 30 (no padding) has an X size of -50, indicating that it actually (correctly) causes adjacent views to be pulled left along with it. However, ActualBounds always has a positive , and if an implicit content offset is being applied (e.g. because of negative margins) then it will be reflected in and not affect the ; the previous example would have position X = -100 and size X = 50 (30 content + 20 right margin).
In terms of usage, is generally used for the layout itself ( and of parent views) whereas is preferred for click and focus targeting.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.ClipOrigin
member.summary: Origin position for the .

remarks.para: If clipping is enabled by specifying a , and the computed size of the clipping rectangle is not exactly equal to the view's , then this determines how it will be aligned relative to this view's boundaries.
The default origin is the view's top-left corner (0, 0). This property has no effect unless the view's is also defined.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.ClipSize
member.summary: Size of the clipping rectangle, outside which content will not be displayed.

remarks.para: This is defined as a layout, but unlike the view's , it is not computed against the available size provided by the parent; instead, its reference size is the view's .

A common scenario is to set this to in order to prevent drawing outside the view's own boundaries, i.e. as an equivalent to CSS overflow: hidden. Note however that clipping occurs during the drawing phase, so a smaller clip region does not result in a smaller layout; the view will still have the same size it would have had without any clipping, but only part of it will actually get drawn. This can also be used intentionally to create some animated visual effects such as slides and wipes.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.ContentBounds
member.summary: The true bounds of this view's content; i.e. excluding margins.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.FloatingBounds
member.summary: Contains the bounds of all floating elements in this view tree, including the current view and all descendants.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.IsFocusable
member.summary: Whether or not the view can receive controller focus, i.e. the stick/d-pad controlled cursor can move to this view. Not generally applicable for mouse controls.
member.remarks: In other game UI code this is more typically referred to as "snap", since there is no true input focus. However, focus is the more general term and better explains what is happening with e.g. a text box.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.PointerStyle

member.remarks: As with , the lowest-level view takes precedence over any higher-level views.

member.name: P:StardewUI.IView.ScrollWithChildren
member.summary: If set to an axis, specifies that when any child of the view is scrolled into view (using ), then this entire view should be scrolled along with it.

remarks.para: For example, if the view lays out children horizontally, and some children may occupy only a very small amount of space near the top while others are much taller vertically or positioned near the bottom, it might be desirable to configure this with , so that the entire "row" is positioned within the scrollable viewport.
In other words, "if any part of me is made visible via scrolling, then all of me should be visible".

remarks.para: Expects a value that represents the fraction of the view's computed layout size. For example, (0, 0) is the top left, (0.5, 0.5) is the center, and 1, 1 is the bottom right. null values are equivalent to .
Origins are not inherited; each view defines its own origin for its specific transform.

member.name: M:StardewUI.IView.FocusSearch(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,StardewUI.Direction)
member.summary: Finds the next focusable component in a given direction that does not overlap with a current position.
member.remarks:
If is out of bounds, it does not necessarily mean that the view should return null; the expected result depends on the also. The base case is when the focus position is already in bounds, and in this case a view should return whichever view can be reached by moving from the edge of that view along a straight line in the specified direction. However, focus search is recursive and the result should reflect the "best" candidate for focus if the cursor were to move into this view's bounds. For example, in a 1D horizontal layout the rules might be:
If the is , and the position's X value is negative, then the result should the leftmost focusable child, regardless of Y value.
If the direction is , and the X position is within the view's horizontal bounds, and the Y value is negative or greater than the view's height, then result should be whichever child intersects with that X position.
If the direction is and the X position is negative, or the direction is and the X position is greater than the view's width, then the result should be null as there is literally nothing the view knows about in that direction.
There are no strict rules for how a view performs focus search, but in general it is assumed that a view implementation understands its own layout and can accommodate accordingly; for example, a grid would follow essentially the same rules as our "list" example above, with additional considerations for navigating rows. "Ragged" 2D layouts might have complex rules requiring explicit neighbors, and therefore are typically easier to implement as nested lanes.
member.param: The current cursor position, relative to this view. May have dimensions that are negative or outside the view bounds, indicating that the cursor is not currently within the view.
The direction of cursor movement.
member.returns: The next focusable view reached by moving in the specified , or null if there are no focusable descendants that are possible to reach in that direction.

member.summary: Finds the child at a given position.
member.remarks: If multiple children overlap the same position, then this returns the topmost child, i.e. with the highest .
member.param: The search position, relative to the view's top-left coordinate.
true to prioritize a focusable child over a non-focusable child with a higher z-index in case of overlap; false to always use the topmost child.
Whether to exclude views whose is currently false.
member.returns: The view at , or null if there is no match.

member.name: M:StardewUI.IView.IsDirty
member.summary: Checks whether or not the view is dirty - i.e. requires a new layout with a full .
member.remarks:
Typically, a view will be considered dirty if and only if one of the following are true:
The has changed
The content has changed in a way that could affect layout, e.g. the text has changed in a configuration
The availableSize is not the same as the previously-seen value (see remarks in )
A correct implementation is important for performance, as full layout can be very expensive to run on every frame.
member.returns: true if the view must be measured again; otherwise false.

member.name: M:StardewUI.IView.IsVisible(System.Nullable{Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2})
member.summary: Checks if the view is effectively visible, i.e. if it has anything to draw.
member.remarks: While acts as a master on/off switch, there may be many other reasons for a view not to have any visible content, such as views with zero , layout views with no visible children, or labels or images with no current text or sprite.
member.param: Optional position at which to test for visibility. If not specified, the result indicates whether any part of the view is visible.

member.remarks: Most views should save the value of for use in checks.

Override this at your own extreme peril. Frequently performing any layout-affecting logic in this function can negate the performance benefits of a retained-mode UI and cause the UI to become sluggish or even completely unresponsive. Do not use it for animation; use instead.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Layout.Edges.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses an value from a comma-separated string representation.
member.remarks:
The behavior depends on the number of comma-separated tokens in the string, equivalent to the constructor overload with that number of parameters:
A single value will give all edges the same length
Two values will set the horizontal (left/right) and vertical (top/bottom) lengths
Four values will set each length individually
Any other format will throw .

member.name: T:StardewUI.Layout.FloatingElement
member.summary: Provides independent layout for an relative to its parent.

remarks.para: This is primarily useful for annotations, callouts, or elements that are intentionally drawn outside their logical container such as scrollbars or sidebars. Floating views can receive focus and clicks, but do not actually capture the cursor like an would, and therefore shouldn't be used for modal UI.

In general it is preferred to use standard layout controls like over floating elements, but there are specific cases that justify floats, such as the aforementioned scrollbar which should display "outside" the container regardless of how nested the container itself is - i.e. the float must "break out" of the normal flow.

member.param: The floating view to display/interact with.
Specifies how to position the relative to the parent and its own measured size.

Floating views can receive focus and clicks, but do not actually capture the cursor like an would, and therefore shouldn't be used for modal UI.

In general it is preferred to use standard layout controls like over floating elements, but there are specific cases that justify floats, such as the aforementioned scrollbar which should display "outside" the container regardless of how nested the container itself is - i.e. the float must "break out" of the normal flow.

member.param: The floating view to display/interact with.
Specifies how to position the relative to the parent and its own measured size.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Layout.LayoutParameters.GetLimits(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2)
member.summary: Determines the effective content size limits.

remarks.para: Limits are not the same as the actual size coming from a ; they provide a maximum width and/or height in the event that one or both dimensions are set to . In these cases, the caller usually wants the "constraints" - e.g. a text block with fixed width but variable height needs to know that width before it can determine the actual height.
Implementations of will typically obtain the limits in their method in order to perform internal/child layout, and determine the content size for .

member.param: The available size in the container/parent.
member.returns: The size (equal to or smaller than ) that can be allocated to content.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Layout.LayoutParameters.Resolve(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2,System.Func{Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2})
member.summary: Resolves the actual size for the current .
member.param: The available size in the container/parent.

Function to compute the inner content size based on limits obtained from ; will only be invoked if it is required for the current layout configuration, i.e. if one or both dimensions are set to fit content.

member.name: M:StardewUI.Layout.Length.Resolve(System.Single,System.Func{System.Single})
member.summary: Resolves an actual (pixel) length.

remarks.para: This is a convenience method for common layout scenarios, where content length is relatively simple to compute. Its use is optional; complex widgets can use any means they prefer to compute .

The result is intentionally not constrained to , which is only used for the method. This allows callers to check if the bounds were exceeded (e.g. to render a scroll bar, ellipsis, etc.) before clamping it.

member.param: The remaining space available.
A function to get the length of inner content. Will not be called unless the requires it.
